remixed_from.author: MrJohn
remixed_from.title: USB Cable Held Fan Mount for RAMPS

description.text:
The feedback I received about my first iteration of this model lead me to redesign it into this. This one rests on the top of the Makergear Mosaic (M1) frame. It can fit in the space where the X Axis is or right above the Z lead screw as seen in the photos.
The only bolts required are the 2 M3 needed to mount the fan to this thing.
I chose to make it like this because I have wired the fan in to the 12v PSU for my RAMPS. I occasionally have to transport my rig to MakerPlace here in San Diego and I unplug everything. So when I pull the plug I can just take the fan off with the PSU.
I am always looking for a better, simpler solution to these types of problems, so if you have a better way that doesn't require diving into firmware or soldering anything, please teach me.

Print, mount fan, place on frame, wire fan to the 12v green connection on RAMPS.
I printed this one in 15 minutes using Slic3r. I have included the gcode in case anyone wishes to try my settings. Keep in mind I use the upper right corner of the bed as my home.

title: Fidget Spinner - One-Piece-Print / No Bearings Required!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Fidget Spinners are a popular toy all around the world... this design provides the same ability to 'fidget' as any other 'Fidget spinner' however it is a one-piece-print with no metal bearings required. It should be almost ready to spin straight off the build plate!

The design features four designed in bearings. With a well sliced file printed on an accurate / precise machine the bearings should be free or take very little effort to break free straight off the build plate. As soon as the bearings have been freed add a small amount of lubricant to the moving bearing surfaces (refer images) and you're in business... ready to give your 'Fidget Spinner' a good spin. Is it as good as a spinner with metal bearings... probably not but they should still spin very well and are definitely fun to fidget with!

You can spin your Fidget Spinner in several ways... a smooth running spinner can be spun in just one hand by holding it in the centre then flicking one of the arms from the top or bottom... or you can get a faster spin by hitting one of the arms with a finger on you other hand. As there are four bearings designed in you can also hold one of the outer bearings and flick the spinner around using them instead of the centre bearing (refer images)

TIP: Once all four bearings have been freed apply a good spray of silicon spray or other light lubricant into the grooves between the main body and bearing on both sides of the spinner. Silicone is an amazing lubricant and a simple way to make 3D printed surfaces move really well against each other.

WARNING: To achieve a great result printing this design you need a good slicing app and accurate / precise machine due to the fine clearances applied. Although the clearances used should work satisfactorily with most slicing apps and machines others may find it a challenge and fuse the parts together. Usually fused parts can be freed however the alternative is to uniformly scale the design up by 5% which will increase the internal clearances.

'LOOSE' Version: A 'loose' file version has been added for members who have issues with printing fine clearances. This increases the clearance by approx. 0.1mm. On accurate / precise machines this will be too loose and the bearings will not run as smoothly as they do with the standard clearances. However, the 'loose' version should allow people with less accurate / precise machine and slicing apps to still get a good result.

'CENTRE' Version: This version is the same as the standard version but has just a single centre bearing. The other three bearings have been removed and the areas they occupied are simple closed surfaces. However, internal cutaways have been added to build shells in these outer areas which may help add a bit of weight to help it spin better.

'FLAT' Version: These two files were added in addition to the above due to member requests for versions that but not have recesses in the centre of the bearings. In these versions (one with four bearings and one with just a centre bearing) the bearings are flat so no recesses to hold with your fingers. There is no other difference.

This is an easy print of a fun gadget but does require an accurate / precise slicing app and machine to achieve the necessary clearance between the moving parts so it will spin well and freely. Applying the lubricant is also essential to getting a really good spin and being able to spin it with just one hand (Metal bearings require lubrication too so this just requires the same).

Retaining the standard scale is recommended to maintain the designed in clearances and also ensure sufficient space between your thumb and forefinger for it to spin. However, you can get creative with colours by pausing your machine multiple times mid-print and changing filament... print in your favourite color or color combination to make your own unique 'Fidget Spinner'.

Everyone needs their own 'Fidget Spinner' and they make great gifts as well... and with this design you don't need to buy any expensive metal bearings to achieve a similar result. Will a spinner with metal bearings spin better or longer... probably due to the added weight but this does a pretty good job at much lower cost and it's entirely 3D printed!

Have fun... and please post images of your 'Fidget spinners in use for other members to see.

Please refer to the print settings / instructions and images for additional information. Higher than usual shells and infill is recommended as this adds weight which will help your spinner maintain momentum.

Note: If you like this check out the rest of my fun and practical designs.

WARNING: To achieve a great result printing this design you need a good slicing app and accurate / precise machine due to the fine clearances applied. Although the clearances used should work satisfactorily with most slicing apps and machines others may find it a challenge and fuse the parts together. Usually fused parts can be freed however the alternative is to uniformly scale the design up by 5% which will increase the internal clearances.

'LOOSE' Version: A 'loose' file version has been added for members who have issues with printing fine clearances. This increases the clearance by approx. 0.1mm. On accurate / precise machines this will be too loose and the bearings will not run as smoothly as they do with the standard clearances. However, the 'loose' version should allow people with less accurate / precise machine and slicing apps to still get a good result.

Clean up, spray with silicone lubricant then give it a spin...

This 'Fidget Spinner' will print well when printed from a well sliced file on an accurate / precise machine. The printed-in bearings will need to be broken free by wriggling them or, if necessary adding a fraction more force (...but being as gentle as possible) with a craft knife to clear away any visible excess filament. With a good slicing app and well set up machine the bearings should be able to be broken free by hand (i.e. no tools required).

Once all four bearings have been freed apply a good spray of silicon spray lubricant into the grooves between the main body and bearing on both sides of the spinner. Silicone is an amazing lubricant and a simple way to make 3D printed surfaces move really well against each other.

This has been test printed numerous times to ensure the expected function can be easily achieved with minimal effort... and you don't need to buy any metal bearings!

comments.author: mirobane

comments.text: You can remix it for your own use... no objection to that. However, when people post derivatives sometimes they have issues and members have a habit of going back to the originator for support. I test print everything I post multiple times but, while they work well for most people, there's still always the odd few that have issues. I do the best I can to help them get a solution, and the issues are slicing app and/or machine related, but can't support files that have been altered from my own. As it is I get hundreds of emails a week from Thingiverse members requesting all sorts of things so try and minimise things that are beyond my control so I have time to respond to these requests.

title: Yet another Ramps+Arduino Mega 2560+LCD 12864 + tinyfan enclosure

description.text:
• Thi kit as been designed to be printed in several parts then glued together.
  • In view of commissioning the second extruder I needed a fan extender. This small device hangs out from the Ramps board, then I had to design larger enclosure.
  • In the prototype I designed the slots for two fans, but after printing I found out that one is noisy enough and in any case I don't have enough space for both of them.

I originally designed all the slots using several 3d models of Ramps+Arduino and LCD12864 found on Internet.
Then, I realized that my hardware didn't match 100% with 3d models. It was slightly different, specially in connectors size and position.
For the same reason I preferred to design the front board separated by the rest of LCD shell
I left some clearance around the slots, so I don't expect that you can have too much problems, but if you really need some adjustments ask me and I'll make your dedicated STL file.

I also put my name on the top lid and on the LCD shell. If you want your own, ask me and I'll prepare a dedicated STL file for you.

Printer:

D-bot Core-XY

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 mm but 0.15 should also be ok

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Supports needed only for LCD enclosure supports

Hardware needed

Some drops of CA glue
Some M3 screws
Some M3 nuts
1 fan 40x40x10 mm

Instructions for Ramps enclosure

Put the M3 nuts inside their pockets
Glue the right rail and the front rail (green) on the bottom baseplate (black).
Glue the right side (red), the front side (green) and the rear side (orange) on the baseplate
Slide the board inside
Connect the left side (blue) with the previous assembly using two screws
Connect the top lid (yellow) using four screws

Instructions for LCD 12864 enclosure

Put the M3 nuts inside their pockets
Glue the button rail (red) to the front board (white).
Glue this assembly to the LCD shell (dark grey)
Turn the assembly upside down
Slide the reset button (bronze) into the button rail
Put the LCD 12864 into the shell
Connect the bottom lid (orange) using four screws
Glue or simply connect by pressure the two blue supports using the four slots into the bottom lid

Finally you can attach the LCD to the board enclosure by sliding the blue supports in the rails on the yellow top lid.

I created this adapter to mount a grill (150x150mm) and a 120mm 12V fan to the wall on the outside of our house.  It features a water drain at the bottom.  
I use this fan to remove excess CO2 from the house.

Infill: 20% (I tried 10%, but 20% gave me better results)
Number of shells: 2
Layer height: 0,30mm Print both side and mount them together. You can use glue for that. Then slide the fan it (cable at top) and mount the grill on it. Drill holes in your wall and mount everything to the wall with screws. I use this with a fan to remove excess CO2 from the house. The CO2 levels are monitored with a Netatmo module. Raspberry Pi reads the CO2 levels from the Netatmo API. If it is above a certain levels the fan will be switched on (I defined 3 different speeds and CO2 levels for that). I use a PI weather daughter board of web4robot dot com to switch the fan. I plan to monitor the outside temperature too, and if it comes below a certain point the fan will switch off (due to the minimum operating temperature of the fan). I use a Papst 4412F/2GL fan because of the low operating temperature and cheap price.

Morabaraba, also known as 12 Men Morris, is a game played competitively in many parts of the world. See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morabaraba for more information and rules. Alternatively you can ignore the diagonals and use only 9 pieces per side to play 9 Men Morris.

The plates are sizes as-is to print on a TOM ABP. Which means they should be able to print on anything. By clever arrangement it may be possbile to print all 4 board pieces at once.
  • Print 4 each MorabarabaBoard.stl
  • Print 2 each MorabarabaPieces.stl in two different colors for each side.
  • Aquire 48 5mm magnetic balls known as buckyballs.
  • Use a flat tipped machine screw to insert the magnetic balls into the board and each piece.
  • Assemble the board. When assmebled there will be a hold in the middle.
  • Make friend.
  • Play Morabaraba with your friend.

This is a PDF version of my latest book on 3D printing. The past year has been very exciting, and I really wanted to share as many of my AM related experiences and experiments as possible. If you are just starting out with 3D printing, then I hope that this book will help you avoid a lot of the stupid mistakes that I made with my Makerbot. If you are a veteran of the field then I hope that my quirky and contrarian take on things will inspire you to try some similarly unconventional approaches. This book is completely self published and was written without the extensive support and back up of the large publishing houses that I am used to. It is therefore certainly not as polished as Hod and Melba's 'Fabrication', or Kirk Hausman's recently released '3D Printing for Dummies.' The main advantage of doing it by myself was that I did not have to answer to a big company editor, and could therefore be quite controversial in parts. Mine is a much more personal take on the subject, and although it might not appeal to more conservative purists, it should strike a chord if you are a hobbyist or home tinkerer like myself. The book features a wide range of industry pioneers, both printer builders as well as end users, all making some very interesting products. Their cooperation was invaluable in putting this book together and I hope that you will support their work if you possibly can. This book is also available at Amazon.com in Mobi format for Kindle Readers as well as a traditional paper version. Adventures in 3D Printing by Christopher D. Winnan
http://www.amazon.com/dp/1494728745 In both cases I have tried to keep the cost as low as I can. If you enjoy the PDF version then I hope that you can help me spread the word about the two retail versions. Although I am keen to share, a man has still got to eat. Please feel free to pass this PDF version of the book along to anybody that you think might enjoy it. If you have access to a Makers' Club or Hackerspace, then please consider posting the attached promo sheet on your message board. If you would like to make the download available on your website then that is cool too. If you could send me a link, then that would be great. Although my first book on the subject, '3D Printing -Â The Next Technology Goldrush' is still receiving positive reviews, being nearly a year old, it is quickly becoming rather out of date. http://www.amazon.com/dp/B00B1UKZC6 This is a very fast moving technology after all. I uploaded that book onto various torrent trackers last year, but I would be happy to put a copy up here if enough people are interested. I am afraid that I do not have any translations available just yet, although there is a distinct possibility of a Mandarin version soon, and a French version later in the year.

At the same time, sales of the mobi and paper versions have spiked enormously since I posted here, and this just goes to show that idea of lost sales due to filesharing is a complete fallacy.  The reality is that every single reader is a potential ambassador and should therefore be treated with respect, not as criminal pirates.  My deepest thanks to all of you for helping to spread the word.

title: Galaxy S7 Edge Car Mount with QI Charger

description.text:
This is just another Galaxy S7 Edge Car Phone mount . It has a built in QI charger mount , which uses the cheap 70mm QI Puck chargers available on EBAY .
I designed this one because i have a leather case on the phone & needed a mount that would accommodate the case size.Internal measurements are 85mm x 170mm, so if you aren't using a similar case then you would be better off using one of the many other designs available .

A QI puck mount attaches to the back of the holder with 4 x 12mm x 3mm countersunk screws.
A commercially available suction mounting arm can be used & adapted to the rear of the puck mount . The one in the photos uses 4 self tapping screws to attach the puck mount to a pad on the suction arm. Many other suction arm versions could be used with some creative mods for mounting . A magnet mounting recess hole is also provided , as it matches my leather case .

.

title: Prusa Mendel i3 Z endstop Tuner

description.text: We needed a easier way to tuner the Z endstop on our Prusa Mendel i3, as reworked by eMotionTech (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:119616). The original Endstop, while being very solid was not easy to tune precisely. So we took the idea of using a screw to tuner the relative position to the endstop and ... Voila ! ;) Works like a charm and make our life much easier ! ;)

-Print all 3 Parts
-Then glue together part1 and part2 (we used acetone to merge these two parts (ABS printed))
-unscrew/remove the original zendstop holder (and endstop)
-install the endstop to the part1+2 group
-using longer screws, fix part1+2 to the bottom left 2 motor
-same thing here fix part3 on the X axis motor
-screw a bolt (with a tuning nut) on part3
-then use the bolt to adjust Z endstop relative position
-enjoy !

comments.text: This design worked great. I would wait to glue all of the parts. The reason being is because you might want to move the vertical peice back or forward so that the tip of the endstop switch will hit dead on the bolt. I did not do this and the bolt hits the lever a little bit down from it. It's not going to hurt it, but is annoying.

description.text:
Basic vise used for clamping pcbs while soldering. Can be used for anything else too though.

threaded rod should be printed upright with the knob on the bottom.
sled should be printed with tapped hole upright on the shorter side.
frame should be printed as is with support structure. holes and clip slot have to be drilled out and sanded after print.
clip should be printed on its side.

These settings worked well when printed in pla on my Kossel delta:
0,2mm nozzle
0,1mm layer height
1mm shell thickness
35% infill
20mm/s speed
197°C
95% Flow

Threads should be retapped after printing if printed with lower settings.

a drill template for 7mm body posts
2mm hole at the top

I created this for my girlfriend for her birthday after i took her to see the Wrath of Khan at the cinema and to her surprise and mine she loved it. the version in the picture was created by shapeways in there sterling silver and in stainless steel. print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
This is a high detail globe of Earth's topography (highly exaggerated), designed as an educational tool. Several others exist on Thingiverse already - the difference of this one is that the outline of the continent has been raised slightly so that familiar coastlines can be picked out, making it better for teaching.

Included are two hollow hemispheres which print with minimal plastic, without supports. Also included a complete sphere for anyone who wants to print using a more advanced method or to use this model for a different purpose.

Suggested things to study:

  • Hawaii, in the Pacific Ocean, is part of a long chain of submarine mountains. These are volcanoes, formed as the ocean plate passes over an unusually hot part of the Earth's interior (a "hot spot" or mantle plume). How many of these tracks can you find?
    • Mountain belts - these form at convergent plate boundaries, where one tectonic plate collides with another. The Himalayas are a great example of this; how many more can you find?
  • Ocean trenches exist where one plate subducts (descends beneath) another, giving a band of extremely deep ocean. The deepest of these is the Mariana trench, in the northwest of the Pacific ocean. Where else can you find subduction happening? Why are the trenches often next to a belt of mountains?
    • A ridge runs down the middle of the Atlantic Ocean - this is where oceanic crust is created. Where are the other mid-ocean ridges?

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Printed without a raft or supports; the hollow sections are able to bridge at the top. To get a good quality print with minimal infill, I suggest the following guidelines:

  • Print with at least 6 base layers 10 top layers - this will give you a good finish over the infill
  • Print with two walls, slowly! There are lots of direction changes in the outer skin, so I printed at 60 mm/s for the infill but only 20 mm/s for the exterior. If your printer is very rigid, you may be able to go faster.
    • Make sure your z-height is well calibrated. The better the first layer, the better the seam...
Glue two halves together with superglue. I printed in HatchBox Silver PLA @ 200C, which looks great...

Surface height data source: ETOPO1 (https://ngdc.noaa.gov/mgg/global/global.html)

Surface height was scaled using a black-to-white monochrome image generated using the Generic Mapping Tools (GMT - http://gmt.soest.hawaii.edu). A second image was generated depicting the coastlines, and these were combined using ImageMagick tools.

The 3D model was created by applying this image as a bump map to a standard sphere in Blender (https://www.blender.org/) and exporting as an STL.

The model was sliced into hemispheres and hollowed out using MeshMixer (http://www.meshmixer.com/).

comments.text: Really appreciate the detailed instructions, thank you.
comments.author: BP9930

comments.text: You're welcome!
comments.author: BP9930

description.text:
The Lion of Saint Mark, representing the evangelist St Mark, pictured in the form of a winged lion holding a Bible,[1] is the symbol of the city of Venice and formerly of the Republic of Venice, as well as of the Greek Orthodox Patriarchate of Alexandria, See of Saint Mark. It appears also in both merchant and military naval flags of the Italian Republic. The Lion of Saint Mark is also the symbol of the award of the Venice Film Festival, the "Golden Lion", and of the insurance company Assicurazioni Generali.

Other elements often included in depictions of the lion include a halo over his head, a book, and a sword in its paws.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Companion paint rack to my http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2183545 (Paint Rack for Eyedropper bottles -180). Some friends wanted a rack for paint pots as well as the rack I drafted up for eyedroppers. It had to fit in the area they had available on their work space. I do not know how many bottles it would fit, which is really dependent on the bottle sizes, since I only have a small assortment of eyedropper bottles (as per provided pics). The design I have provided could easily be modified by anyone with a modicum of Inkscape or similar vector manipulation skills.

This template is formatted for cutting on one 3mm MDF sheet cut to (Arch C) 24" x 18" - which I cut on the bed of an Epilog Helix. I have provided the PDF and a SVG files that I converted online at https://cloudconvert.com/vsd-to-svg, which you may customize to your own needs. Shared as is.

If you are inclined to be more than a taker and a consumer, pay forward by contributing to this site, as so many others have before you, or perform a random act of kindness, or donate to a good cause when the opportunity next arises. And if you download this, please LIKE, it helps get the word out and spread these designs around. That is all.

description.text: At some point these workmate springs, that keep the legs from folding in, out will wear. And since the workmate is rather old, I heard that this replacement part is discontinued. Hence this printable design. You can either choose to print it with support yourself, or download the design for which I already included suitable support.

Printer:

Custom Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.5 mm nozzle, 0.1 mm layer height

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Choose a thick wall, I used 3 perimeters with 0.5 mm width and 1 mm solid top bottom layer.

comments.text:
I used the stl file with supports. I needed to clean the small notch (for sliding in the steel sheet of the Workmate) very well, then it fits like a glove. Works like the original.
I would advice to "lubricate" the sliding surface with a fingertip of vaseline. Then the legs slide much easier but still stay properly locked in position.
Thanks for the design!
comments.author: gerlag

comments.text: I'm glad you like it and thanks for sharing your experiences. I made mine from ABS because it is more flexible than PLA. Keep me informed how PLA behaves over time.
comments.author: gerlag

comments.text: I'm not sure if ABs is more flexible. According to https://www.3dhubs.com/knowledge-base/fdm-3d-printing-materials-compared PLA is even stronger than ABS and both have similar "elongation at break". On the other side, the impact resistance of ABS is much better. We'll see, I keep you informed anyway. Hopefully it will take some time ;).

I was having difficulties printing at high temperatures (over 245C). Jams happened daily due to heat creep , so I decided I give the coldend more cooling.

According to specs 3010 and 4010 fans pretty much do the same airflow and static pressure they just use dirrefent RPM to achieve it.
I was looking for more and some 5015 radial fans offer almost 5 times as much static pressure and around +50% CFM so I went for it and never turned back:)

Printer:

CoreXY

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

15%

Notes:

I used PETg which can flex a bit but ABS is also great.
Wouldn't use PLA due to radiating heat (but most likely you can get away with it just fine -
please comment if you had luck with it).

2 perimeters
4 top layers
3 bottom layers

Fun part:

You just clip in the 5015 fan (it should be a tight fit) then screw the adapter to the E3D fan holder.

comments.text:
Works great !!!
And very sure it is blowing more air than the previous fan.

title: VORON Y Axis Alignment Tool Dial Gauge holder

description.text:
Adapted the VORON Y Axis Alignment Tool to incorporate a dial gauge.
This one has been designed for a dial gauge with an 8mm shaft. Specifically this one from Amazon UK.
There is a 1mm lip near the bottom of the main hole to hold the gauge in place.
I've also added a 3mm hexagonal hole to the front so you can thread a set screw in to secure the dial gauge if needed.

There should be enough room to drill out the top part of the main hole if your dial gauge has a larger diameter shaft.

  • No supports needed.
  • Nozzle size, layer height, shells/perimeters, infill shouldn't matter too much - just be sensible!
  • Print with you favourite material.

For info the one pictured was printed in PETG, 0.4mm Nozzle, 0.28mm layer height and about 30% infill.

author: PeterS1

title: Colorful light from IKEA Pyssla beads

description.text:
My daughter loves the Pyssla beads from IKEA - the ones you can heat with household iron and make colorful shapes off them. So we decided to make a LED lamp from them:

  1. Print the base on 3D printer.
  2. Make 5 colorful squares (10x10) from the Pyssla beads and flatten them with hot iron.
  3. Use hot glue to make a cube from the squares.
  4. Solder wires to the top part of LED legs (near the base). Solder single wire to each LED, one to anode and second to cathode of the other LED.
  5. Bend legs of two LEDs to right angle and put them into the base. Solder them parallel.
  6. Create battery contacts from thin sheet metal. I used a nickel strip used when making battery packs because I had it, but you can use metal from cans etc.
  7. Solder the wires to the metal contacts.
  8. Power with AAA batteries.

The light does not have any on/off switch, because I don't have any locking switch such small at the moment, You can modify the base to fit the switch from bottom, if you wish. We are removing the batteries to turn it off.

remixed_from.title: Lm8uu X Carriage with Fan Mount for Prusa Mendel

title: Auto Z Stop with Lower X Axis for Prusa Mendel i2

description.text:
This is work in progress
Up Date: 2018
The Floating z Axis is preforming very well, the micro switch option works with marlin's
auto level feature, using the hot end as the probe.
I have not done any more on the tool holder. Up Date: 2014
I added a Micro Switch to the lower "X" Axis. nuts and bolts on
each side of the switch can be used to set the height to trigger
the micro switch. This switch is wired (n/o) when in contact with
"X" carriage this will close, completing the "Z" circuit. I have been designing a Lower X Axis for tools/accessories to be
used during the printing process. By putting the Extruder/Hot end
in a standby mode. Then have the X carriage connect to one of
the tools/accessories on the lower X axis, then do it's work.
Park the tool/accessory and continue printing. After seeing Radus's "Auto Touch Z-End Stop" for the Prusa i3,
I believe this could be an option for an
Auto Z end stop / Bed Leveling System
for the Prusa i2. The Rods for the Lower X Axis do Not need to be installed to
use the Z auto stop function.
There is also a file with the lower X rod clamps removed. This does not reduce printing area.

Sending a Thanks out to of the other designers / builders
for their Designs that Inspired this project.

Needed:
Wire For auto Z stop circuit
4 Lm8uu Bearings for Z (or printed bearings might work)
2 - 4 Lm8uu Bearings for Tool Holder(s)
2 - 8mm Smooth Rods same length as upper X (for lower X axis)
8 -12 longer screws 25mm to 30mm (Holes print as m3)
16 - 20 nuts
8 wire to screw connectors The screws will be use as a contact point.

I used the Judo Fish Idler & Motor Mounts as a guide for the
spacing of the screws in the Lower X axis mount. Print 2 of lower mounts, there is no left and right.
(There is support material that needs to be removed by the
clamps for the Lower X axis rods, these are thin walls and
come out easily) turn off ALL power to printer. Remove the X axis from printer
Remove the nuts and springs from your existing x axis Idler &
Motor mounts. (You will reuse these) Remove current Z stop switch
Install longer screws in the Motor and Idler mounts and tighten
the 1st nut to hold the clamps.
Install the longer screws in the new Lower x axis mounts
assemble Lower X axis with springs and nuts.
have both smooth surfaces Lower X axis and the existing
Idler and Motor Mounts facing each other.

Attach wire to screws, tighten the 2nd nut to hold the wire
connector in place. Connect all contacts in series
Connect the remaining 2 wires of the new circuit you just
made to the original Z stop wires.

Check your Software for Z end stop setting.
It needs to be N/C. (Normally Closed) As Z lowers the hot end touches the print bed,
the upper X axis will stop and the lower X axis will continue
moving down seperating a contact opening the circuit.
This will tell the software that Z is at lowest point. I have seen conversion about keeping the current Z stop as a
failsafe. This could prevent damage to printer. (not a bad idea)
Wire it in series with the other contacts if you plan to do this.
Check switch for N/C.

The Lm8uu Carriage with Fan Mount for Prusa Mendel is the
carriage used for the print head. Extra material where needed.
Dual fan option,Nice and Compact. This will be modified to
capture the lower X axis tool/accessories carriage.

The Compact LM8uu x-Carriage will be modified to become the
Lower X Axis carriage. This will hold the tools/accessories that
will do some type of work. I like the low profile and good capture
of the Lm8uu bearings

Planning to use this as my Z stop and manually level the bed. I don't have the Auto leveling software upgrade yet,
(Upgrading to an auto bed leveling system, is on my to do list). Will update and the project progresses

description.text:
This used to be a remix of Bernis great idea of using magnetic force instead of springs to push a ballbearing against an extruder gear to feed filament into the hotend.
I'm currently using it on my HyperCube to gather it's performance with different filaments. So far I've just tested with PLA and it performs very well. Using a 470mm long PTFE tube between hotend and the extruder my retraction settings are
length: 4.5mm
speed: 45mm/s
which works very well with no stringing appearance.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

25% cubic

Notes:

Lever should be printed with the long flat surface down.

Parts needed

.) printed baseunit, lever and Rändelschraubenkopf
.) 2xneodym magnets 10x10(dxh) N45 3.9kg holding force
.) NEMA17 stepper
.) 2xM3 nut
.) 3xM3x25 allen screw
.) 1xM3x20 allen screw
.) 1xM5x12 allen screw
.) ball bearing 16x5x5(odxidxw)
.) MK7 Teeth Extruder Gear
.) 1xPush Fitting PC4-M6
.) approx 1cm PTFE tube

comments.text:
Of course I meant the push force exercised by the extruder on the filament. I don't think people are interested in the force exercised by the magnets. Now, if you wish feel free to compute it and then compute the push force on the filament.
If you can explain the advantage compared to a simple spring would be nice too. To use magnets as spring, clamp, dampener, actuator ... is quite common but needs to bring some advantage !

title: 3DR Solo Gimbal Holder for GP Hero 4 Black (no weights)

description.text:
I made this gimbal holder specifically for the 3DR Solo and the Hero 4 Black. It is designed to snap into place and hold the Hero 4 Black securely. A generic version of this found elsewhere on Thingiverse has a large opening for the counter-weights used on the Hero 4 Silver and Hero 3+ Black. It will not hold the Hero 4 Black securely. This one will.
It has been modeled so that the opening is centered over the GP display. It has also been created to fit better and look better. There is adequate clearance for a lens hood or lens cap.

A GoPro lens cap model has also been included.

description.text:
I wanted to use my KEF T101 Speakers in the Horizontal Layout like the T101C/T301C Center Speakers. However, KEF only delivers the metal clip for the back with the center speakers. So i decided to print my own.

There are 2 Versions: Normal & Big. The BIG is when you decide to turn around the speaker so that the openings for the clip are on the top instead of the bottom.

edit

I updated it to Version 2

This one is much more stable. It doesnt matter if ABS or PLA. Instead of just reproducing the KEF original Stand, i am using the Wallmount Holes of the Speaker. This one is also usable for both orientations of the speaker. Simply plug one stand in and move it a bit to the left or right according to the wallmount. For added stability you can add the support structure.

title: The Ultra Grippy Door Stop // SodaMan
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
With its small form factor and ridged bottom for extra grip, the 'Ultra Grippy Door Stop' is perfect for keeping your doors open! Its ridges help it to grip carpeted floors and the angle of the top helps to keep the door securely in place!

If you have any suggestions about how I can improve the design, then let me know in the comments! There is also a version with my logo on the top if you want something that looks a bit more interesting.

Update 17/10/17:

I added a version 2 of this design; its smaller, and therefore takes less time to print and uses less material. It is also shorter in height, so if your door is exceptionally high then might not work. On standard doors, it will be fine.

The spikes on the bottom are optimised for extra grippiness!

title: Parrot Bebop 2 mounts for Lowepro DroneGuard CS 300

description.text:
Lowepro makes excellent cases for drones. That you may know.
Their DroneGuard CS 300 is designed to carry Bebop one with some accessories. That you may know as well.
But the big question is - can you fit there Bebop 2 with Skycontroller 2 - and some accessories..?

Well... Yes! And if you will print mounts designed by me, and fit them to Lowepro case using velcro with glue, you may run, walk or hike, jump or whatever comes to your mind - your Bebop 2, Skycontroller 2, two batteires and smartphone holder will move with you, but not inside the case ;)

Enjoy!

comments.text:
Hi,
The overhang angle you can print without needing support material will depend on the ratio between layer height and extrusion width.
By reducing the layer height to 0.05 mm I can print with very high overhang angle in the bottom of the part.
If you don't want to print with this low layer height you can just add support material and print with any layer height you want. Not very much support material is needed.

title: Ultimaker Electronics Cooling Duct
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Unfortunately the original Ultimaker radial fan is from crapy quality.
This thing replaces the whole cooling assembly.
Inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/Sonarok/designs conformed to a more practical thing. You can use it with a 40mm fan and don't have to print extra feet. I've used a Noctua fan and messured 24dB(a).
Also Noctua provides all adapters you need to stick the 3-Pin Connector on your alsways on 12V port. (regular fan)
Edit: It's an always on 19V (18.8) Port.
So you may want to use a 24V Fan. I soldered a voltage regulator on it...

• Print all two parts
  • (opt) cut threads in the holes of the fanholder
  • Mount fan with M3x12mm
  • Screw the Parts with M3x6mm together.

comments.text: The design works as it is, thank you for that :-) However, some issues in case someone does a redesign: the fanduct presses down on the fan connector (see photo in my make). And it doesn't blow air directly to the L7812 which needs it the most, according to a comment in the Ultimaker group.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I my case they're both no problem.

Take the L7812 comment with a grain of salt, maybe... I'm just checking the electronics schema, and the L7812 is used for nothing else but powering the 12V electronic fan. I'm not sure why (or whether) it should get hot, compared to the motor drivers (which definitively need cooling). I can actually touch the L7812 (with cover removed) it while it's driving the fan, it's not hot (but it hasn't been running long, and I'm not printing). I re-checked the comment on the UM group, I repoduced it correctly here, so either the new fan uses much less power, or the comment was wrong, or I'm not testing it right.
comments.author: LukasQ

comments.text: I just plugged in the old fan, and... ouch! Now the L7812 does get hot.

Actually, no voltage regulator is needed. The fan connector delivers 12V already, however if only USB is connected it delivers 5V, which is not enough to start the Noctua fan. And switching from 5V to 12V doesn't start it neither, it needs 12V right from the beginning. But you can simply remove the ARD_PWR jumper on the board (see photo in my make; feel free to add it). Then the fan will never be powered by USB so it will always start.

title: Rear Anet A8 LCD mount for Raspberry Pi 3 with camera (IMPROVED)

description.text:
This is a remix of the Raspberry Pi 3 with camera mount for the back of the LCD panel on the Anet A8 here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2185490

@bma801did a great job and he said he does not even have a pi3.

After I starting putting an actual pi3 install in place, I needed the following improvements:

  • Added a slot cutout into the top cover for the camera cable

  • Changed the camera to have TWO hinge connectors instead of three. The three on three was difficult to connect because they were off-center, and because they were too thick. I replaced the original three on the camera back, with two thinner ones more like the extension arms he had designed. The three arm camera back is still recommended if you are using the extensions though and still included in the zip.

description.text:
This is a simple basic enclosure for a uselessbox. It uses one single 9G servo and can hold a 9V battery for powering. There is enough space to place little PCBs or put the wiring for the useless box inside. My box is powered by a Attiny13 which gives the ability to run nine differnent programs to turn off the switch. This gives the box a moody personality :-)

The design is very easy, needs no support to print and only has small overhangs which are easy to print.

Youtube: https://youtu.be/ycmA8jxt45w

Firmware for the Attiny can be found here:
https://github.com/ringo2k/uselessboxfirmware

Connect the Servo PB0 and the switch to PB4 and thats it (more in the README).

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/7OvPWIVaO2F

comments.text: I'm interested in making this, but I have a question. According to the data sheet, the ATTiny13 has an input voltage of 1.8v - 5.5v. Did you put a resistor on the VCC input to the IC, or did you use a different variation of the chip? Also, what was the value of R1 on your schematic?

comments.text:
Sorry for the late answer, i used a 7805 voltage regulator to make 5V out of the 9V. I added the regulator in the schematic.
R1 is for the LED, it depends on your LED but you can use 1k and your LED should light up :-)

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Hi,
Also if now GEEETech proposes the Acrylic Prusa I3 pro series, B for single extruder and C for dual extruder, with metallic idler, I’ve see lot of people that still download my old customization for Printed idler, so I’ve think good to “port” the new version of my customization also on old, printed idler!
Here the Dual Extruder FAN & LED component of my new customization.
In this design you can find place to put ties in order keep in position all cables, as you can see in my photos!
For FAN Duct you can find closed & open version, I prefer closed one but I know that lot of people can love open version!
The component is designed to support also the 3DTouch sensor that GEEETech is released to implement ABL!

PS: I’ve also add the STL for carriage with some small enhancement compared to original GEEETech ones, for example the x belt fixing method copied from the metal carriage, really more easy to put in place, and Nut space on extruder holder where screw add-on!

As usual in all my design I’ve splitted all in order to have an easy print of each part, and also an easy mounting after print!

IF YOU “FALL IN LOVE” OF THIS DESIGN, PLEASE, REMEMBER THAT IT TAKE TIME TO BE CREATED, DESIGNED AND SHARED… SO “MAYBE” YOU CAN USE THE “TIP DESIGNED” BUTTON ON MY PROFILE!

title: drawers with inlay-shelves  for Raaco 150  and Powerfix magazines

description.text:
When you have a hobby that requires a lot of small parts, like electronics, you may already have several magazines that are filled with resistors and capacitors, different semiconductors and many small mechanical parts like switches, connectors, jumpers, small nuts and bolts. Especially when you develop you own stuff, you want to be prepared and you probably have the standard components in all values, typically the E12-series for carbon resistors and the E24-series for SMD-resistors. Typical small parts magazines have drawers that can be divided into 2 to 4 compartments and 8 rows of 4 to 5 drawers. This gives a maximum space for 854=160 different values. An E24-series from 1Ω to 10MΩ has 192 values and would thus exceed one Raaco-magazine.
Most of the space in such a magazine is occupied by air and it is obvious that more compartments per drawer is the solution.
The standard partition walls for the drawers in the usual small parts magazines divide in one dimension, from back to front. These drawers here divide into 3 dimensions. We have rows and columns and levels in the shape of inlay-shelves.
In Raaco- and Powerfix-magazines they can be removed and they typically slip out when two neighboring compartments are filled with 1000s of smallest parts and you want wo take out one of them. Thus the partition walls are fixed. The ability to print them yourself gives enough flexibility.

If you download and unpack the .zip-File, you can choose one of the pre-built STL-files which are named this way:

    <model>_<shelves>x<rows>x<columns>.stl for the drawer
    <model>_<shelves>x<rows>x<columns>-inlay.stl for one shelve.

The default values in the file are for Raaco 150-0 drawers.
If you want to Create a Powerfix drawer, you can use the outcommented values in the .scad-File or you can use the following Values in customizer:

width = 68;
height = 36;
length = 118;
grip_depth = 8;
grip_height = 8;
grip_frontheight = 26;
grip_downshift = 1;
griphole_diameter = 16;

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

n.a.

Notes:

The grip is designed to be printed without support.

First remove the brim, especially well on the inlay-shelves!
If you want to store electrostatic sensitive devices, I suggest to spray the insides with graphite lacquer as you can see on the first image.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
As we know there is nothing worse than Clementines arriving at parties without the proper attire. This is the solution! A beautiful hat that combines modern art, catwalk fashion and affordability.  
Also compatible with Mandarins and Satsumas.

Constructed in Cinema4D. Created a Tube primitive then selected the faces and performed various extrudes, all within a Hyper Nurbs. Lower faces were angled slightly to give the tilt at the lip of the hat. Finally the hole on the protruding piece was cut out with a cylinder using Booleans, then the edges were bevelled slightly.

I finally got to the point that I couldn't fit all my chucks in my lathe stand (A horrible state of affairs...not!). These mounts are set up so you can screw them onto a board and mount your Hardinge chucks! AND they keep junk out of the taper! The locking mechanism works just like on the Hardinge: slide onto the slot, and turn to lock. They are not particularly tight, though. The lock pin will ensure your chucks don't slide off, though.

Printer:

WeldingRodBot

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Coarse is OK

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I am printing these with a Volcano nozzle: 1.2mm!
You want at least two shells with a 1.2mm nozzle. With a normal nozzle I would go with at least 4 shells.
Make sure that your support system leaves some gap between the support and the walls near it! The supports are needed; unfortunately, you can't taper the lower surfaces; the lock pin needs to interact with them, and needs the square corner.

After printing, you have to remove the supports from the locking slot. I've modified these from the Hardinge standard so that you can take a saw (I use a drywall saw) and cut along the bottom edge. When you cut through into the gap, stop. I used a chisel to trim the supports off of the top edge.
Clean off any bumps on the tapered surface.
Run a drill bit through the mounting holes, if needed.

Almost four years ago, I took my personal daily headphones to a shooting and lend them to the sound operator. At the end of the day, the little joint between the structure and one of the headphones had broke. I remember myself clearly saying "No worries, sooner or later I'll get a 3D printer, learn some CAD and repair this". That day has come and I have new headphones again.

I started the design in TinkerCad as the noob I am to 3D print/design. After three trials, I got a piece that fitted almost perfectly, but printed crappy filament and only 15% infill it broke after a couple of days. Then redesigned the entire thing via OnShape and printed again with RigidInk white PLA and 100% infill. It's been a week and it keeps hanging on!

title: Save the last Unicorn [Game]
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hey,

here is my first designed game - inspired from an old TV-show: Save the last Unicorn!

How to play:

  • take the wand and hammer min. one stone out of the game
  • give the wand to the next player
  • if the Unicorn falls down you lose =(

Here you can find a short gameplay: https://youtu.be/Nk5TLTX8QNQ

What do I need to print?

  • 1 x Wand
  • 1 x Frame
  • 4 x Leg
  • min. 36 x Stone (try the fit with your printer with 6 stones and if it fits print the rest)
  • 1 x Unicorn
  • 1 x Unicorn-Stone

Let me know if you got any questions or problems with the design!

Happy gaming and check out my other designs too!

title: Evil Spool Hanger
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This holder is meant to be screwed into the wall above and behind your printer. Hang your spool on it and feed the line into your printer.

The holder has 4 screw pilot holes.

The post is wide enough to hold any of the spools that I have. If you have something wider, let me know.

Having the spools overhead makes it a lot easier to load the filament on my FFC dual.

Suggestions for improvements are gleefully accepted.

Notes:

I printed using

PLA
Temp 200/60
speed 75/75
.2 layer
3 shells
10% infill.

If you have trouble printing the post, try

0% infill.
10 shells.

No raft or support material should be needed.

After the print cooled, i took a mallet and pounded the post into the hole in the wall piece.
It is held in place by friction.

I mounted it with 2 short wood screws.

This is a parameterised belt tensioner, for those times when you just don't want to take everything apart to fix the belt tension properly! It can be put on, adjusted, and removed easily and takes up only a small amount of space.

Print two. Clip them both onto the belt, facing opposite directions as in my photo. Then fold them in over each other and use an M3 bolt (30mm long) and nut to fasten. Keep tightening until the belt is how you want it.
I printed mine with standard fill (30%). You may want to use more plastic.
Tighten up!

print_settings.Notes:: case

title: plant watering system - compact case for RPi 1, 4 relay module & 5pcs Hygrometer module

description.text:
English

Everybody who plants vegetables, herbs, flowers... on the balcony knows it: the plants need to be watered once or in hot times even twice a day. So I made a watering system with a small water pump, a single-board computer and some small electronic parts. The case is 3D printed to make the whole thing look nicely!

I'll publish pictures and the required scripts on my website (http://www.cEnz.at) after I have finished everything. For now I'm uploading the before mentioned case as well as a step-by-step instruction for the cabling.

The case is designed for the Raspberry Pi 1 - Model B (Rev. 2) but you can edit it for any other single-board computer. If you do so please publish a remix of the modified parts.

The caps are available 29 and 30 mm though the pins are all the same (diameter 26 mm). Please decide for yourself which cap size to use depending on the material you use.

You find the adapter for the D-Sub and the printable cable chain here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2213180

note:
The mini-version is actually small! Please consider that the soldering as well as the cabling takes a lot of time and is difficult. The big-version is intended for connecting without soldering so I recommend this one!

UPDATE 04/27/2017:

  1. There is now another version of the lid (for the "mini"-version) with 1cm more space upwards to connect the GPIO from above (see also photo).
  2. Another pin occupancy for using an MCP3008 (analog-to-digital converter) for reading the soil moisture sensors.
  3. added Breadboard view

Deutsch

Wer in der Stadt wohnt und am Balkon jährlich Gemüse, Kräuter & Co pflanzt, kennt das tägliche - im Hochsommer auch zweimal tägliche - gießen. Mit kleinen Wasserpumpen, einem Einplatinen-Computer und etwas Elektronik kann man sich sein eigenes kleines Bewässerungsystem basteln - und mit einem selbstgedrucktem Gehäuse kann man es auch noch schön verpacken!

Fotos der gesamten Bewässerungsanlage mit den erforderlichen Skripten werde ich nach Fertigstellung (Anfang Mai) auf meiner Webseite - http://www.cEnz.at - veröffentlichen. Vorab veröffentliche ich auf Thingiverse das Gehäuse zum Selberdrucken sowie eine Schritt-für-Schritt Anleitung der Verkabelung im Gehäuse!

Das Gehäuse ist für den Raspberry Pi 1 - Modell B (Revision 2) konstruiert. Mit nur wenigen Änderungen kann man das Gehäuse mit einem anderen Einplatinencomputer (z.B.: Arduino Uno) verwenden! Wenn Du das tust, veröffentliche bitte die geänderten Teile als "Remix".

Bei den Befestigungskappen passten bei mir teilweise die 29mm und manchmal auch die 30mm, obwohl alle Pins einheitlich (Durchmesser 26mm) sind.

Den Adapter für D-Sub und druckbaren Kabelkanal findet man unter:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2213180

Anmerkung:
Die "mini"-Version ist wirklich sehr klein! Das Löten und vor allem das Verkabeln ist zeitaufwändig und sehr umständlich. Die "big"-Version wurde zum Stecken konzipiert, deshalb empfehle ich die "big"-Version zu benutzen!

UPDATE 27.04.2017:

  1. Es gibt nun eine weitere Version vom Deckel (für die "mini"-Version) mit 1cm mehr Platz nach oben, um die GPIO von oben anschließen zu können (siehe auch Foto).
  2. Eine weitere PIN-Belegung, in der ein MCP3008 (Analog/Digital-Umwandler) zum Auslesen der Bodenfeuchtigkeitssensoren verwendet wird.
  3. Steckplatinen-Ansicht ergänzt

Electronic components

4 relay module, 5V:
https://www.amazon.de/gp/product/B01M8G4Y7Z/

module YL-38 for Hygrometer:
https://www.amazon.de/gp/product/B00ZR3B60I/

D-Sub, 25-pin:
https://www.conrad.at/de/d-sub-buchsenleiste-180-polzahl-25-loetkelch-1-st-741698.html

post a comment for other product links, I will supplement the link!

Monoprice MP Select Mini

No

No

0.21875mm

100%

Notes:

I recommend to print the case with 100% infill, so the sticks - to hold the components - are strong enough and don't break so easily. For the other parts 25-30% infill are enough.

English

Pic 1-3:
There's not enough space for the GPIO pins in the mini version. That's why you'd have to unsolder the pins and solder them again bottom-up.
You save a lot of time if you use the big version as there's more space! - OR USE THE NEW TOP (see Update 04/27/2017)

Pic 4:
The power plug was too long so I bypassed it as you can see on the picture below.

Deutsch

Foto 1-3:
In der "Mini"-Version ist nicht genug Platz um die GPIO-Pins anzuschließen. Deshalb ist es erforderlich die GPIO-PINs zu entlöten und von unten neu anzulöten. Diese Prodezur erspart man sich in der "big"-Version (mehr Platz nach oben).

Foto 4:
Der Stecker vom Stromkabel ist zu lang, deshalb habe ich das Problem - wie am Foto unten ersichtlich - umgangen.

Pic 1 Pic 2 Pic 3 Pic 4

print the parts remove the support with a comb pliers the hole should be residue-free test (D-Sub) power distributor (soldering) test (power) soldering two power distributors (vcc, gnd) for the Hygrometer module soldering the led and test it test (place components) D-Sub, 5pcs Hygrometer module and cables (soldering) Let's build it together.... ....laying the cables and modules.... ....place the relay.... ....pull in the power distributor and connect it.... ....connect the relays.... ....and the power distributors (vcc & gnd) for the Hygrometer module.... ....supposed to look like.... ...connect your Pi (or another single-board computer).... ...place the sticks and connect the led... ....power for your Pi (Bypass necessary if you use the mini-version).... ....place the cover for the cables (optional).... ....screw the d-sub (max: M3 x 20mm).... ....now only the top/cover is missing.... ....finished! :)

Once again I say thanks to Hyungsoo Kim who's posting on the Grasshopper forum provided the basic definition for this part. I added additional Grasshopper components, a top and bottom surface, and changed the geometry a bit and make the part 3D printable. My AAtom2 delta-style printer took a little over 24 hours to print this part at a layer height of 0.200 mm and print speed of 100 mm/sec.

Here's a short 3D rotation video showing the part: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VB9xIXqSA1A. The second photo shows the dish with tortellini, cashews, and dried apricots. Not the most appetizing combination, but it's what I had readily available.

More info about Grasshopper, parametric modeling, and how architecture can provide ideas for 3D printing is here: http://birkbinnard.com/blog/

title: Anycubic Kossel TriGorilla Electronics Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These mounts were designed for the Anycubic Kossel with the 200mm build plate. They may work on other makes of this size. Additionally, for larger printers, you could easily modify the rear mounts to suite.

While overall I'm pretty pleased with this printer kit, as expected (and as many of you know), the mounting bracket that comes with this printer is lacking (also, the stupid square nuts). Mainly, the way the board mounts makes the solder joints on the bottom of the board hit the mount. That causes the board to not be level inside the printer. I also don't like electronics only being supported at one end. Also, my mount was in two pieces when it arrived (bad glue joint).

There are some nice designs for replacement here, and some do support the rear of the board, but they use long arms attached to the front. I am planning on adding some cooling to the board and didn't want to worry about any extra load on those arms. So, I went with a 3 piece design.

I used SketchUp to create a model of the printer, including accurate 20X20 extrusions, modeled the board, and then created these mounts.

The front mount gives clearance on the board around any solder joints, and mounts the board on the inside of the 20X20 extrusion. Power and USB are easily accessible and somewhat protected. The rear of the mount is actually two pieces, one on each side of the board. The rears bolt to the rear mounting holes, support the board from underneath and use a single screw and nut in the channel of the rail. One bolt should be enough, as the mount cantilevers against the lower extrusion. The front uses the standard 4 bolt set up.

If you print this you'll need:

1 X Front Mount
2 X Rear Mount (the same mount works on either side)

Printer:

Anycubic Kossel (200mm)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The front mount is doing all the heavy lifting here. The rears just stabilize and support the lighter rear of the board. I used .3 and 20% infill, but you could probably use 10% if you wanted. These aren't holding up a car.

The parts should be oriented correctly for printing already, but if not, rotate them so the "arms" are up.

And yes, I printed these on this printer. The first 'non-test' objects.

These were printed using the PLA that came with the printer. I was surprised it came with a full 1KG roll. Not the greatest PLA I've ever used, but not the worst either.

I love the design of Tech2C's HyperCube, but decided if I'm going to remix it, I may as well make it more capable in terms of build volume. I already have a small scale printer with a 150x150x150 build volume and found that the size prohibited my ambitions.

Ergo, the 45M remix was born.

I named it 45M based on the intended build volume of 300x300 bed and 500 height - ergo 45 million square millimeters :D

Print Requirements

4 x Bed_Supports_45M.stl
8 x z_rail_supports_45M.stl

Rough dimensions were calculated from my raw materials calculator here - http://funkydiver.com/hypercube-materials
This calculator (currently) is designed for single Z axis stepper layout - once I've finalised my design, I'll be updating it to a dual Z layout.

I also used quickbikes remix of the fan duct http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2157334

description.header:
This design improves on the last Bling Carriage by:
(a) adding captured M3 nut cavities for the tensioner(s)
(b)Adding some extra space for the belt to pass thru!
(c) most importantly!, on the non-tension side, add a flex member to ensure top+bottom bearing contact (reduce wobble about the x-axis)
description.text:
This is ALSO a drop-in replacement for the standard mendel x-carriage. It is is inspired by Buback's OpenX Carriage with the following mods: 1) Integrated belt tensioner
2) Fan mounting
3) Some silly features that I think look somewhat artsy/blingin. The intent of the design was to incorporate the 40+mm square space to fit larger profile extruders, while giving the carriage some steez.
I included only the full plate.  I'll try and put up the individual pieces later.  Hopefully you like it!
Requirements are the same as the original, except 1x more M4x>15 screw and 1x more M4 nut.  You'll also have an extra bearing + bearing hardware spare.

description.text:
Custom Alien pez dispenser,
Came across a alien pez someone had made online using a toy but since I couldn't find a figurine I decided to make my own and thanks to Geoffro and his amazing sculpted head I give you the craziest pez
The little mouth will move when you remove all the pez and mount it with the magnets but make sure you have polarity right.
https://youtu.be/evVKO0MVfmk
I had just started using simplify3d and the results are great and supports are easy to remove, just turn down support pillar resolution to the lowest setting.

Pez body needs a little groove cut into it in order to allow the shaft to move through.

On the slider you may have to cut off some plastic depending on the size of the magnet you get but make sure its flush in the slider holder.

When removing the supports the teeth sometimes break since they are delicate but just glue them back on and also included some spare teeth in case you cant find the missing fang,

Also included the laser files I used to make the foam case.

Also doesn't push out the pez a little, it more like spits it out the mouth :D
I have a couple extras I had made available on my etsy page.

description.text:
A version of the hand that is not only more printer friendly than before, it also requires no screws! While the original thing was a great idea, there were two problems with it.

1: If you bought the single piece print (SPP) file like he wanted you to, the tolerances are so low that the joints probably won't free up, I know because I printed this http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:911554, and now it looks like this .

2: The multi piece print (MPP) files weren't designed for 3D Printing either, there was barely anything on the bed, some that printed tall would fall over in the middle of the print.

Since I knew how to fix the problem with the MPP files, I did. There is now a lot more of a first layer for the printer to lay a foundation on, and there should be no loss in performance, look, or really anything. There are also slight modifications, for example, the "Back Right" and "Back Left" have the pins built into them. The only issue is the shield, the only way to fix that was to lob a lot of the back off, seen in "Shield 2." I wouldn't recommend using this file because the shield will not be a strong, but if you have adhesion problems with small first layers, you don't really have a choice.

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

The "Claw" might still need supports, but I'll let you be the judge of that.

There is a little support material on the "Back Left" and "Back Right" that you have to remove, see picture.

Assembly (READ FULLY BEFORE PRINTING)

For one hand, you will need: 1 "Back Left/Right," 5 "Cube Joint," 5 "Finger Pin," 10 "Panel Joint," 1 "Ring Index," 1 "Ring Middle," etc., 1 "Wrist Lock," 5 "Finger Back," 20 "Pin," and 10 "Pin 2."
Optional: For one finger: 1 "Finger Pin," and 1 "Claw." Or: 1 "Shield" or "Shield 2."

Whatever you do, DO NOT PRINT THE "Back Left/Right" BEFORE THE 5 "Finger Back." Because in the middle of the "Back Left/Right" print you will need to insert one "Finger Back" into every hole in that model. Other than that the assembly should be fairly obvious, if not then read the manual, adjusting for your slightly upgraded finger parts.
I really just took the original files, put them in the best orientation for printing, and lobbed the bottoms off.

description.text:
This is a remix of a very nice Spring Winder found earlier of Thingiverse. However, the original one did not meet my particular need as I needed a very special kind of spring, that i made out a 0.8 mm diameter music wire (8 mm inner diameter).

This remix might be part of a biggest project (I will need it to make all the springs used in this future project).

------ Strengths :

  • Very versatile (can handle most of the small springs)
  • Flexible as the handle is designed to receive different size winder (6 & 8 mm by now, but we can redesign the whole thing to achieve other diameters)
  • Easily swappable (you just have to unplug the keys locks) between sizes
  • 6 mm AND 8 mm mandrel holder
  • The mandrel support is designed to receive several mandrel holder sizes as well. The systems also works with keys locks

----- Drawbacks :

  • I need to redesign the holes as my printer cannot handle such small holes very well
  • Extra cleaning is required to get all the pieces nice and clean (small files and 1mm drill bit are highly recommended!)
  • Limited to 1mm diameter wire at the moment.

Printer:

Emotion Tech Prusa i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 or 0.3 mm

Infill:

20 to 35 %

Notes:

Supports are useful for printing the keys fitting holes, however they need extra time to be cleaned properly (as the windows are quite small). If you manage to print the parts correctly without using supports, please let me know! I'm curious to see if we can get a nice part without them.

This is a study of Ugrinsky's wind turbine concept. I didn't found lots of detail about this concept but few sketches can be found and it was claimed as a lot more efficient compared to Savoniu's design. And actually, it is !

I made this design to be printable with a limited quantity of parts. 1 level (H 70mm) = 1 part, meaning that you can add as much level as you want, ending by the top part. Some pictures are showing an assembly of 3 levels, the top and and the base (not yet available).

  • 2 x screws diam.~3.5mm-L~15mm) / level
  • No need for support or printing specification, mine are printed by 0.4mm layer.

More designs of Ugrinsky's concept ?
TanyaAkinora : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:996946
Robotobi : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1718731

Another parts are already designed but the entire concept is still in progress, then only main part and top part are uploadable as of today ... let see if there is an interest on it !
